Department of Chemistry Dicle University Diyarbakır TR-21280 Türkiye As a key method for C–C bond formation, the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling is usually catalysed by homogeneous systems under thermal heating, making catalyst separation difficult and requiring high energy input. Herein, the preparation, characterisation and catalytic/photocatalytic performance of heterogeneous nanocatalysts with BD-g-C3N4 (Benzene Doped Graphitic Carbon Nitride) support material, whose surface was modified with Pd nanoparticles, is presented. The photocatalytic and catalytic activity of the obtained Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalyst was investigated in Suzuki–Miyaura CC coupling reactions of phenylboronic acid and various arylhalides under aerobic conditions and water as sole solvent. The Pd@BD-g-C3N4 catalyst in the coupling of p-bromoacetophenone and phenylboronic acid showed conversion rates of between 73 and 99 % as a photocatalyst under visible light irradiation at 25 °C and as a thermal catalyst at 100 °C, respectively. Furthermore, Pd@BD-g-C3N4 shows very good recyclability and wide applicability for Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Suzuki-Miyaura C-C coupling reaction Palladium Photocatalysis Graphitic Carbon Nitride Nanoparticles Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In recent years, criteria supporting green chemistry, such as the use of non-polluting energy sources and solvents and the prevention of waste generation through the use of separable heterogeneous catalysts, have led to the development of more environmentally friendly chemical processes in both academic and industrial settings [1]. As a renewable energy source, solar energy is the most promising option for the development of photocatalytic systems that collect visible light to direct chemical processes, as i) the majority of sunlight (44 %) is in the visible range, ii) it is environmentally friendly in the execution of photocatalytic processes, and iii) it is an increasingly popular option that is attracting attention every year [2–6]. Aromatic carbon-carbon coupling reactions are of great methodological importance in the preparation of complex organic molecules such as pharmaceuticals, of which Heck [7,8], Suzuki-Miyaura [9,10], Sonogashira [11] and Stille [12] are the most commonly used coupling reactions. They are usually performed at high temperatures using homogeneous palladium systems, which present difficulties in catalyst separation of expensive palladium complexes and poor recyclability. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts offer a significant advantage, as they can be easily removed by centrifugation. The Suzuki–Miyaura coupling is highly important for synthesising biaryl compounds efficiently from aryl halides and organosilicon or organoboron reagents. Extensive research has focused on creating heterogeneous catalysts and photocatalysts for this purpose. Most such reactions are performed under thermal conditions, which involve significant energy usage. As a result, the development of a heterogeneous photocatalytic Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction with minimised energy consumption in organic synthesis is still highly necessary. To achieve more sustainable processes, Pd has been integrated with light-absorbing solar-active materials to provide the necessary energy via photonic excitation and recent studies displayed that Pd-based photocatalysts have been widely applied in photocatalytic organic transformations [13–15]. Semiconductor-catalysed cross-coupling reactions are the most popular, simple and powerful protocols [16,17]. Over the past decade, various photocatalytic supports such as TiO2 [18,19], CeO2 [20,21], CdS [22–24] and g-C3N4 [25] have been continuously developed to immobilise Pd. In recent years, g-C3N4 has emerged as a leading photocatalyst in Suzuki-Miyaura reactions due to its reliable superior photovoltaic characteristics [26]. It is non-toxic, easy to synthesise, low-cost, and offers high thermal and chemical stability, a narrow energy band gap, and thermal absorption in the visible region. Nonetheless, its photocatalytic efficiency is limited due to poor charge separation and rapid recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, which diminishes its catalytic activity [27–31]. Several rational strategies, including heteroatom doping, copolymerisation, and the creation of porous structures, have been employed to address the limitations of g-C₃N₄ [32–36]. Enhancing the number of π-electrons is an effective strategy, as it leads to band gap narrowing in g-C₃N₄, which in turn lowers the adsorption energy and promotes more efficient separation of electron-hole pairs during photocatalysis. To improve photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4, benzene rings are placed into the composite via co-polymerisation from urea and trihydroxybenzene precursors [35]. This method is suitable for preparing benzene-doped g-C3N4, but still, the complexity of the synthesis process creates inevitable defects. It has been demonstrated that incorporating the noble metal palladium into composite materials facilitates electron transfer and significantly enhances their visible light absorption capability [37–41]. In this study, different percentages of palladium by mass (0.1 %-3 %) were decorated on benzene-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BD-g-C3N4) support material by wet impregnation-reduction method using NaBH4 and prepared Pd@BD-g-C3N4 NPs finally characterised by FT-IR (Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy), HR-TEM (High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy), SEM (Scanning Electron Microscope), EDS (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy), XRD (X-ray Diffraction), XPS (X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy), UV–VIS-NIR (Ultraviolet/Visible/Near Infrared Spectroscopy), BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) and ICP-MS (Inductively Coupled Plasma – Mass Spectrometry) analyses. The catalytic and photocatalytic activities of the prepared Pd@BD-g-C3N4 catalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions were examined under visible light irradiation and thermal heating conditions. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All chemicals were purchased commercially and used as received. 2.2 Preparation of BD-g-C3N4 Following the method described in the literature, BD-g-C₃N₄ was obtained through thermal polymerisation [42]. For this purpose, typically 25, 35, or 45 mg of m-trihydroxybenzene [C6H3(OH)3] (phloroglucinol) and 10 g of urea were ground uniformly and separately transferred into two identical crucibles and covered with aluminium foil, respectively. After heating to 530 °C in the muffle furnace with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, the second personnel was removed from the container and sintered at the same temperature for 1.5 h. The prepared samples were labelled as BD-g-C3N4–25, BD-g-C3N4–35, and BD-g-C3N4–45, respectively. The products were fully characterised without subjecting them to any washing or purification processes. There was no need to pump or purge the system with any inert gas during preparation. To serve as a reference, g-C₃N₄ was prepared by the same thermal polymerisation method without the incorporation of m-trihydroxybenzene. 2.3 General method for preparation of Pd@BD-g-C3N4 Pd@BD-g-C3N4 NPs were obtained through a standard aqueous-phase impregnation-reduction technique carried out in one step [43] with different percentages of palladium by mass (0.1 %-3 %). In a typical synthesis (2 % loaded Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35), 7.66 mg Pd(NO3)2.H2O (5 mL) and 150 mg BD-g-C3N4–35 (30 mL) were dispersed in pure water in separate containers using a sonicator. The resulting Pd(NO3)2.H2O solution was added to the Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 solution with a magnetic stirrer and stirred for 1 h. At the end of the period, NaBH4 (15.9 mg; 5 ml pure water) solution was added dropwise to the mixture and Pd+2 metal was reduced (30 min.). The resulting product was filtered, washed with pure water (4 × 15 mL) and ethanol (4 × 15 mL) and dried in a vacuum oven at 353 K for 2 h. A light green-colored Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 catalyst was obtained as the final product. 2.4 Characterizations Electronic properties of samples by UV–VIS-NIR (Shimadzu UV-3600 Plus) spectrophotometer, elemental composition and chemical state by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos AXIS), micro and nano structures scanning electron microscope (SEM, ZEISS EVO 50) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI TALOS F200S TEM 200 kV ), determination of functional groups by crystal structure X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/MAX-2200, λ = 0154 nm Cu) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR, Agilent Technologies Cary 630 FTIR) spectra, specific surface areas nitrogen adsorption and desorption experiment BET (Micromeritics ASAP 2460). To determine the Pd loading (wt %), the powdered sample was completely digested in aqua regia (1:3 HNO3/HCl, v/v), and analysed using Thermo/ICAPQ inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. 2.5 General procedure for photocatalytic Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions The photocatalytic performance was evaluated through Suzuki–Miyaura C–C coupling of phenylboronic acid and p-bromoacetophenone under aerobic conditions using a visible light source (Osram 300 W ULTRA-VITALUX) equipped with a cut-off glass filter transmitting λ > 420 nm in a reactor equipped with a water-cooled quartz jacket at ambient temperature. For this purpose, firstly, 1.0 mmol p-bromoacetophenone and 1.5 mmol phenyl boronic acid, 2.0 mmol base, 5 mL solvent, 0.01 mmol catalyst were transferred to a quartz glass reactor vessel. Stirring 30 min. catalyst-substrate adsorption-desorption balance was achieved by keeping it in the dark with a magnetic stirrer. Then, samples were taken (2 mL) at regular intervals and purification was performed by flash chromatography using acetone. Following these procedures, the conversion rate of our biaryl product was examined in GC (Gas Chromatography). 2.6 General procedure for Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions A detailed description of the procedure employed for the catalytic Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reactions, along with the analytical methods used for product characterization, is available in our recent publications [44–50]. 2.7 Catalytic/photocatalytic recycling of Pd@BD-g-C3N4 catalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions The catalytic stability and reusability of Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄ NPs were tested over five consecutive runs of the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling between p-bromoacetophenone and phenylboronic acid in water, using 0.01 mmol Pd. Following the first cycle, a fresh batch of reactants (1.0 mmol p-bromoacetophenone, 1.5 mmol phenylboronic acid, and 2.0 mmol base) was added to begin the second catalytic cycle, and the mixture was stirred until the second reaction was complete. This process was carried out for a total of five catalytic or photocatalytic coupling cycles. Product yields were calculated under the assumption that p-bromoacetophenone, being the limiting reactant, was completely converted 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphological properties of 2 %Pd@BD-C3N4–35 The crystal structures of the prepared catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1 , were analysed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) between angles of 10°-90° The pure Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄-35 sample exhibits two characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 27.5° and 13.2°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) lattice planes, respectively. The intense (002) peak at 27.5° is linked to the stacked conjugated aromatic layers of BD-g-C₃N₄, indicative of its layered structure, while the peak at 13.2° arises from the ordered polycondensation of tri-s-triazine units in the (100) crystal plane (JCPDS 01–087–1526) [51]. Diffraction signals at 2θ = 38.3°, 44.5°, 64.8° and 83.2° are characteristic of Pd (111), (200), (311) and (222) crystal formed after loading Pd NPs are the diffraction peaks. Additionally, the XRD results were evaluated against the JCPDS card (#05–0681), confirming that the synthesised palladium nanoparticles possess a face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure, as previously reported [52]. FT-IR spectroscopy was applied to identify Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄-35 and revealed that its chemical structure is almost the same as pure BD-g-C₃N₄, suggesting that Pd loading did not induce any structural distortion (Fig. 2 ). After the addition of Pd NPs, no visible change in the main characteristic bands of g-C3N4 was observed, indicating that there is a non-covalent interaction between BD-g-C3N4 and Pd NPs in the composite [53]. The peak at 806 cm-1 is typical triazine (C3N3), and the peaks at 1403, 1455, 1540 and 1630 cm-1 are the peaks of characteristic plane bending and stretching vibrations of g-C3N4 belonging to heptazine ring units. Two additional absorption peaks located at 923 and 1504 cm-1 are attributed to the in-plane stretching vibrations of the BD-g-C3N4 aromatic benzene ring and the stretching vibration of the C=CC aromatic skeleton compared to g-C3N4 [54]. In addition, the peaks at 1228 and 1314 cm-1 belong to CN (-C or -H)-C formation, and the peaks at 3100–3400 cm-1 belong to a small amount of amino (OHNHNH2) group stretching vibration. The UV–Vis Diffuse Reflectance (UV-DR) technique was used to determine charge carrier generation and to estimate the band gap energy of the Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalyst. Fig. 3 shows that the absorption wavelengths of BD-g-C₃N₄ and Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄ are around 443 nm and 452 nm, corresponding to approximate band gap energies of 2.79 eV and 2.74 eV, respectively. According to the Tauc plots ((αhν)² vs. hν and (αhν)¹/² vs. hν), the extrapolated band gap values from the x-axis intercepts are 2.97 eV and 2.94 eV (direct transitions), and 2.80 eV and 2.76 eV (indirect transitions) for BD-g-C₃N₄ and Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄, respectively (inset of Fig. 3). The observed modification in electronic structure can be attributed to enhanced absorption in the visible region, driven by the combined effect of Pd–Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄ interactions and the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) of the metallic Pd nanoparticles [55]. The surface elemental composition and the oxidation state of Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalyst and the decoration of the Pd nanoparticles on the composite were examined using XPS analyses (Fig. 4 (abc)). Firstly, as seen in the spectrum in Fig. 4a, Pd NPs were successfully decorated on the support material without affecting the crystal structure. An additional Pd 3d doublet is observed in the Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄ sample compared to BD-g-C₃N₄. In Fig. 4b, the XPS spectrum reveals intense peaks at 335.9 and 341.3 eV corresponding to Pd(0) (3d₅/₂ and 3d₃/₂), and weaker peaks at 336.9 and 342.0 eV corresponding to Pd(II), which may originated from the surface oxidation of palladium nanoparticles during the XPS sampling procedure[49,56]. These results confirm the successful deposition of Pd nanoparticles on the BD-g-C₃N₄ surface without altering its crystal structure. Moreover, the XPS spectra in Fig. 4c show N 1 s energy levels at 397.8, 396.4, and 399.5 eV, C 1 s levels at 282.6 and 286.1 eV, and O 1 s peaks at 529.8 eV, 533.1 eV and 534.0 eV. The N1s region in the typical XPS spectra of BD-g-C3N4 comprises four distinct peaks. The peak at 398.2 eV is attributed to sp²-hybridised aromatic nitrogen atoms bonded to two carbon atoms (Fig. 5 ). In contrast, the peak observed at 399.7 eV arises from bridging nitrogen atoms connected to three sp²-hybridised carbon atoms within the C–N framework (N-(C)₃). In the XPS C1s spectra of BD-g-C3N4, the primary peak observed at 287.8 eV is attributed to sp²-hybridised carbon atoms within the carbon network, specifically in the N CN configuration. A secondary peak at 284.6 eV corresponds to graphitic carbon (C=C), which is typically present as a contaminant or due to the adsorption of CO₂ gas. This peak also served as the reference for calibrating the binding energies of the elements in the XPS analysis. Within the BD-g-C3N4 structure, carbon atoms are bonded to three nitrogen atoms, forming a conjugated polymeric framework [57]. To further examine the presence of Pd nanoparticles and the micro- and surface structure of Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35, SEM-EDX analysis was performed. Fig. 5a and b show the SEM images of BD-g-C3N4–35 and Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35, and when these images are examined; i) It can be seen that Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 has the characteristic nanosheet morphology similar to BD-g-C3N4–35, so the morphological structure of BD-g-C3N4–35 was not distorted after loading Pd nanoparticles on the BD-g-C3N4–35 support material (Fig. 5b) ii) No bulk metals of observable size were found on the surface of the BD-g-C3N4–35 nanosheet. Additionally, no bulk metallic Pd was detected on the surface of BD-g-C3N4–35. Elemental composition analysis of the sample was performed using EDS. As seen in Fig. 5c, EDS analysis confirms the presence of C, N, O, and Pd. EDS analysis was conducted on a localised area of the sample to quantify Pd content, assuming the sample exhibits a homogeneous composition. The loading of the samples in the form of % wt Pd onto BD-g-C3N4–35 was determined as 1.8 by ICP-MS analysis. HR-TEM and EDS techniques were utilised to characterise the crystallinity, structural stability, polydispersity, particle size, and morphology of Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35. The TEM micrographs presented in Fig. 6 for the sample containing 1.8 wt % Pd demonstrate these features in detail: (i) As seen in Fig. 6a, the BD-g-C3N4–35 has relatively thin sheets; (ii) The formation of bulk metallic palladium at a visible scale outside the Pd nanoparticles was not observed; (iii) Pd NPs were highly dispersible in BD-g-C3N4–35, no aggregation occurred; (iv) Fig. 6(b) allowed for the average diameter of the PdNPs to be determined to be about 6.4 nm (in the range of 3–10 nm, Fig. 6(f)); (v) The interplanar spacings of PdNPs were depicted in Fig. 6(d). The d-spacing was estimated to be 0.127 nm. (vi) The presence of palladium metal in the novel Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 catalyst was confirmed via EDS analysis (Fig. 6(e)). In the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, as seen in Fig. 7 a and b, the surface areas of BD-g-C3N4–35 and Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 are 45.37 m²/g and 34.65, respectively. In the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore diameter analysis, the pore diameters of BD-g-C3N4–35 and Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 were determined as 8.42 and 4.11 nm, respectively. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity determination of Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions Firstly, the effectiveness of different amounts of benzene-doped g-C3N4 support material (25, 35 or 45 mg) and different loading (wt %; 0.5; 1; 2; 3) of Pd catalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions was photocatalytically investigated by under UV–visible light irradiation, K2CO3 as a base, and water as an environmentally friendly sole solvent as seen in Table 1 . For this aim, an Osram 300-Watt Ultra-Vitalux lamp with UV-visible radiation was used as the light source. The amounts used in the reaction were optimised based on studies in the literature [44,58–60] and the reaction was carried out at room temperature. A conversion of 76 % was obtained under these conditions with the use of Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄-35 catalyst containing 2 wt % Pd (Table 1, entry 7). The control reaction employing BD-g-C3N4–35 did not yield any product in the photocatalytic coupling of p-bromoacetophenone and phenylboronic acid in aqueous K₂CO₃ solution after 6 h at room temperature (25 °C). (Table 1, entry 16). It was also observed that all photocatalysts showed an increase of conversion by up to 4 h, but this conversion was towards unsubstituted biphenyl which is the homo-coupling by-product at the 6th hour, as seen in Table 1, entries 13–15. The photocatalytic reaction can also be performed on a gram-scale, giving the desired product a nearly identical yield (Table 1, Entry 17). 3.3 Catalytic activity determination of Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions The effect of varying Pd loadings (0.5, 1, 2, and 3 wt %) and different quantities of benzene-doped BD-g-C3N4 (25, 35, and 45 mg) on catalytic efficiency was investigated in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of phenylboronic acid with p-bromoacetophenone, carried out in water with K2CO3 under reflux and aerobic conditions, as presented in Table 2 . Under these reaction conditions, 98 % conversion was obtained in five minutes with the 2 % wt loading Pd@ BD-g-C3N4–35 catalyst (Table 2, entry 7). The catalytic reaction can also be performed on a gram-scale, giving the desired product a nearly identical yield (Table 2, Entry 13). 3.3.1 Study of optimization The most active catalyst for Suzuki-Miyaura CC Coupling reactions was tested using different solvents (DMF, H2O, EtOH, Dioxane), bases (K2CO3, K3PO4, Cs2CO3, KOH) to increase the catalytic or photocatalytic activity under aerobic conditions. The reaction did not progress without the presence of a base, as it was necessary to activate the boronic acid (Table 3 , entry 10). Temperature studies were performed at 25 or 100 °C only for catalytic tests. A series of optimisation studies were carried out as seen in Table 3. In catalytic and photocatalytic reactions, the best results were obtained when K2CO3 was the base, the solvent was water and the reaction temperature was 100 °C (for catalytic conditions) (Table 3, entry 4). Reactions were performed three times to test the reproducibility of catalytic/photocatalytic results. In an additional test, we assessed the catalytic and photocatalytic activity of Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 in the coupling of phenylboronic acid with p-chloroacetophenone in water. The reaction proceeded less efficiently than with p-bromoacetophenone, likely due to the stronger Ph–Cl bond (96 kcal/mol), which is harder to break than aryl bromide bonds (Ph-Br: 81 kcal/mol) (Table 3, entry 9) [60–62]. Encouraged by the favourable results, the study was expanded to test different aryl bromides and phenylboronic acid under the optimised conditions. The catalyst effectively promoted Suzuki–Miyaura couplings with a range of aryl bromides (both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituted) and iodobenzene, resulting in good to excellent conversions. In contrast, photocatalytic reactions gave only moderate yields (Table 4 ). For example, iodobenzene reacted with phenylboronic acid in just 10 min with a 99 % yield under thermal catalysis, while 77 % conversion was obtained in 5 h under photocatalytic conditions (Table 4, entries 3–4). The photocatalytic efficiency was further assessed using a series of substituted aryl bromides and iodobenzene under identical reaction conditions (Table 4, entries 1–6b). However, the catalyst exhibited reduced activity and selectivity in the coupling of aryl bromides with phenylboronic acid. Notably, the presence of electron-donating substituents negatively impacted both the conversion rates and selectivity of the desired coupling products [Table 4, entries 5,6]. Error bars showing standard deviations calculated from three independent experiments for each catalyst are shown in Fig. 8 . 3.3.2 Recycling experiments One of the main benefits of heterogeneous catalysts is their excellent stability and recyclability. The reusability of Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄-35 was thus tested in catalytic and photocatalytic Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reactions using phenylboronic acid and p-bromoacetophenone as model substrates, with 50 mg of catalyst under optimal conditions (Fig. 9 ). Fig. 9 (a, b) clearly shows that the Pd@BD-g-C₃N₄-35 catalyst can be reused for up to five cycles with minimal loss in both catalytic and photocatalytic efficiency. After the fifth cycle, the catalyst maintained 88 % of its original catalytic activity and 63 % of its photocatalytic activity in the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction. There was a slight decrease in catalytic or photocatalytic activities of Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 catalysts during the five consecutive runs. Fig. 9(c) shows the TEM image of the Pd@BD-g-C3N4–35 catalyst after its use as a catalyst in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reactions. Compared to the initial particles, the TEM image of the solid sample displays larger aggregates, which are most likely a consequence of particle agglomeration during the catalytic reaction. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we report a novel Pd@BD-g-C3N4 (2 % Pd loading) nanoparticle for photocatalysis or thermal catalysis of the Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reaction. This catalyst was characterised by FT-IR, HR-TEM, SEM, EDS, XRD, XPS, UV–VIS-NIR, BET, and ICP-MS analyses, which confirmed the identity of elements and functional groups in the sample. The Pd was found to be present as Pd nanoparticles on BD-g-C3N4. Due to the good light absorption of BD-g-C3N4 and the excellent catalytic activity of Pd NPs, Pd@BD-g-C3N4 exhibits good to excellent catalytic performance for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions with conversions between 73 and 99 % as a photocatalyst under visible light irradiation at 25 °C and as a thermal catalyst at 100 °C, respectively. Moreover, Pd@BD-g-C3N4 shows very good recyclability and wide applicability for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions. The results of this study may provide recommendations for the development of a new type of catalyst for aromatic CC coupling reactions, which are methodologically extremely important in the preparation of complex organic molecules. Our study offers an eco-friendly and sustainable route for carrying out Suzuki–Miyaura C–C coupling reactions. coredata.dc:description: As a key method for C–C bond formation, the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling is usually catalysed by homogeneous systems under thermal heating, making catalyst separation difficult and requiring high energy input. Herein, the preparation, characterisation and catalytic/photocatalytic performance of heterogeneous nanocatalysts with BD-g-C3N4 (Benzene Doped Graphitic Carbon Nitride) support material, whose surface was modified with Pd nanoparticles, is presented. The photocatalytic and catalytic activity of the obtained Pd@BD-g-C3N4 nanocatalyst was investigated in Suzuki–Miyaura CC coupling reactions of phenylboronic acid and various arylhalides under aerobic conditions and water as sole solvent. The Pd@BD-g-C3N4 catalyst in the coupling of p-bromoacetophenone and phenylboronic acid showed conversion rates of between 73 and 99 % as a photocatalyst under visible light irradiation at 25 °C and as a thermal catalyst at 100 °C, respectively. Furthermore, Pd@BD-g-C3N4 shows very good recyclability and wide applicability for Suzuki-Miyaura CC coupling reactions.
